text: We'll hear argument next in No. 86-1879, National Treasury Employees Union v. William von Raab.
Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
xxx be a warrant--
Well, Your Honor--
--on that basis.
--We have... we have... the government has never really made an argument that it should be freed of the traditional requirements of the Fourth Amendment.
Well, are you arguing that in order to justify these tests that there must be a warrant?
I... we have... we did preserve that argument, Your Honor.
Thank you, Mr Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
Mr. Solicitor General, may I ask this question?

It is an element in the balance, and I think that's an important point to talk about because it's hard to argue... and nobody seriously argues... that the government does not have a very serious interest in assuring that those who are on the front line of drug interception are not themselves involved in drugs.
Mr. Solicitor General, may I interrupt because I don't think we should talk about applicants.
The incidence is certainly small, and we do not contest that.
Well, but your tests show it to be nonexistent.
Not nonexistent.
Not among... among transferees?
--Yes, sir.
Let me just first interrupt and ask you.
--At the time the case was tried, I believe that there were no positives which were shown up in the transferee population.
But did you... but at that time was there any record of people who withdrew or who... who otherwise would have applied for a transfer?
--Well, I don't think... I don't think records were kept--
Yes, of that.
--of people who withdraw And in fact it's rather important that they not be kept--
Yes.
--because the withdrawal process is one which is quite free.
Well, that might... if there were a lot of withdrawals, I suppose that might be one explanation you didn't find anybody.
That's right, or people who simply don't apply.
Would that... would those be the figures that Ms. Williams gave us?
--I think so.
How long had the program been in effect at the time the case was tried?
--I think about somewhat between a year and two years, Mr. Chief Justice.
But, again, let me just... let me just... so you have time to address it.
--I think that you're comparing, with respect, apples and oranges because the point of probable cause is to focus and... to focus and to confine discretion.
But are you saying then that the probability of finding something is not relevant to the analysis?
The probability is not relevant to the... I have... I have--
That isn't what you said earlier.
--No.
--Are they compelled to file financial disclosure statements such as Justice Scalia suggested?
--Well, of course, some of these people--
I mean, do you regularly look at their bank accounts and find out what their financial status is?
--No, we do not, but there is--
Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.
Thank you, Ms. Williams.
